official-title.#text:
To amend the Public Health Service Act to provide for the
		  establishment and maintenance of an undiagnosed diseases network, and for other
		  purposes.

cosponsor.#tail:
) introduced the following
			 bill; which was referred to the

short-title.#text:
Charles August Long Undiagnosed Diseases Research and
			 Collaboration Network Act of 2013

CAL Undiagnosed Diseases Research and Collaboration Network
			 Act of 2013

text.#text: This Act may be cited as the

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: the following:

is amended by
			 inserting after

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#text:
Title III
			 of the Public Health Service Act

header.#text:
The National
				CAL Network of Undiagnosed Diseases

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail: , acting through the

, shall establish and maintain an undiagnosed diseases patient network
				(in this section referred to as the

text.#text: The

The
				purposes of the CAL Network shall be to—

provide physicians who are handling cases
				of undiagnosed diseases with a means, consistent with applicable privacy laws,
				including HIPAA privacy and security law (as defined in

better enable and
				examine cross-disease research whereby cases of undiagnosed diseases can be
				cross-referenced against attributes of common diseases and rare diseases to
				assist in the rendering of a diagnosis; elucidate commonalities; identify
				atypical presentations, rare subgroups, similar findings; and identify
				potential treatments;

make necessary
				data available to elucidate appropriate factors (such as genetic,
				environmental, and occupational factors) that may be associated with the
				various types of cases of undiagnosed diseases reported by individuals
				specified by the

provide such data
				necessary to better understand the length of time for a diagnoses to be
				rendered in cases of undiagnosed diseases and to identify barriers to diagnoses
				and reasons for misdiagnosis of diseases; and

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
, if the needs and number of such
				individuals support—

text.#text:
provide such information necessary to
				determine, in order to improve access of individuals with undiagnosed diseases
				throughout the United States (including those with severe illnesses which limit
				or restrict travel) to programs similar to the Undiagnosed Disease Program
				conducted at the

the expansion of
				such Undiagnosed Disease Program, as in existence as of the date of the
				enactment of this section, to include the establishment of additional
				undiagnosed diseases programs of like scope and nature at other locations
				throughout the United States; and

the establishment
				by entities other than the National Institutes of Health of separate
				undiagnosed disease programs of like scope and nature to the Undiagnosed
				Disease Program at locations throughout the United States under the guidance of
				and through grants provided by and through such Undiagnosed Diseases
				Program.

{http://namespaces.cato.org/catoxml}enti.#tail:
shall include in the CAL Network such
				information respecting undiagnosed diseases as the

deems appropriate
				for the purposes described in

and other purposes to facilitate
				the early recognition, treatment, cure, and control of such diseases.

make the

provide for

allow for an

text.#text: The

the collection,

				disorders that can often go undiagnosed or be misdiagnosed as other diseases or
				disorders; and

the establishment

text.#text: In carrying out this section, the

not later than 1
				year after the date of the enactment of this section, complete any study,

complete the
				implementation of the CAL Network such that it is fully operational by not

term.#tail:
means a medically
				unexplained chronic multi-symptom disease that—

text.#text:
For purposes
				of this section, the term

has not been
				diagnosed by a medical specialist in a tertiary medical center;

is without
				conclusive pathophysiology or etiology;

is characterized
				by overlapping symptoms and signs; or

exhibits an
				inconsistent demonstration of laboratory abnormalities.
